column14: Your trusted literacy partner for over 25 years, Pioneer Valley Books is dedicated to providing educators with high-quality print and digital resources for comprehensive literacy instruction. We offer engaging books and research-based materials to improve educational outcomes and foster a love of reading. Our robust literacy programs empower educators to create the best possible learning experience for their students.

Learn more: https://bit.ly/3HSn1Od", "reactions_count": 6, "comments_count": null, "reshared_post_author": null, "reshared_post_author_url": null, "reshared_post_author_headline": null, "reshared_post_description": null, "reshared_post_followers": null, "reshared_post_date": null, "last_updated": "2023-01-11 20:14:52", "deleted": 1}, {"id": 24203531, "company_id": 7721630, "urn": "urn:li:activity:7008873833604558848", "followers": 762, "date": "1w", "description": "NEW! We've recently added three brand-new phonics book sets to our fabulous Digital Reader app—72 decodable readers! 

The Ready, Set, Go books provide the most novice reader with opportunities to develop concepts of print, such as one-to-one matching and return sweep, as well as practice in decoding using consonant sounds and short vowels.

The On Our Way books provide the beginning reader with opportunities to practice decoding CVC words, words with initial and final digraphs, and simple words with initial blends.

The Building Up books provide the early reader with opportunities to practice decoding words with final blends, long vowels, and vowel teams. digitalreader.com

We are so excited to let you in on our newest secret: a brand new set of Pioneer Valley Phonics Storybooks is on its way to the warehouse. Our Phonics Storybooks sets provide teachers with a collection of high-quality decodable readers carefully crafted to follow a scope and sequence that provides readers abundant opportunities to transfer newly acquired phonics skills to an authentic reading context. Each book features diverse characters, fun storylines, and beautiful illustrations. Ready, Set, Go Set 1 is available to purchase now: https://bit.ly/3BS6d9h 

#phonics #literacy #books  #reading  #readers #teachers #teacher #decoding #decodable #storybooks #school #kindergarten #kindergartenteacher", "reactions_count": 4, "comments_count": null, "reshared_post_author": null, "reshared_post_author_url": null, "reshared_post_author_headline": null, "reshared_post_description": null, "reshared_post_followers": null, "reshared_post_date": null, "last_updated": "2023-01-11 20:14:52", "deleted": 1}, {"id": 24203537, "company_id": 7721630, "urn": "urn:li:activity:6979100873725485057", "followers": 762, "date": "3mo", "description": "The “Science of Reading” (SoR) movement that began in 2018 has gained momentum and has had an outsized influence on state reading policy and classroom practice. However, the SoR movement presents two negative impacts on long-term literacy education—a commitment to the “Simple View” of Reading (SVR) and mandates for phonics-first instruction for all beginning readers. In this webinar, Paul Thomas, Ed.D. (Professor of Education, Furman University, and author of How to End the Reading War and Serve the Literacy Needs of All Students), places the SoR movement within the context of the robust but complex current state of reading science. Come join us on Thursday, October 20, 2022, at 4 p.m. as we explore what’s next in literacy education. Register: https://bit.ly/3qm8aVV 

#education #webinar #literacy #teachers #teaching #reading #teachingresources #professionallearning #scienceofreading", "reactions_count": 5, "comments_count": null, "reshared_post_author": null, "reshared_post_author_url": null, "reshared_post_author_headline": null, "reshared_post_description": null, "reshared_post_followers": null, "reshared_post_date": null, "last_updated": "2023-01-11 20:14:52", "deleted": 1}, {"id": 24203538, "company_id": 7721630, "urn": "urn:li:activity:6970917928988803072", "followers": 762, "date": "3mo", "description": "Meet our amazing panel of educators from our free interactive webinar: Starting Strong with Small-Group Instruction! They cannot wait to collaborate with you on back to school tips and thoughts! Register for our free September 8th webinar here: https://bit.ly/3vp2pcd

• Karen Cangemi has 30 years of experience teaching and coaching and, as a former district literacy coach, worked with underperforming schools to close the achievement gap. 

• Andrea Davis has taught all combinations of 5th, 6th 2nd, and 3rd grades. She also stepped into the role of On-site Instructional Coach and was responsible for delivering professional development, supporting teachers in the classroom and with curriculum.

• Allison Jurado taught 4th and 5th grade for seven years.

• Emily Wayman has taught 3rd–5th grades, Reading Recovery, and worked as a District Literacy K–5th Coach. 

• Marcie Hydrick has taught 1st grade for 20 years. 

• Ruben J. Saldivar has taught 2nd grade and 5th grade since 2007. He also worked one-on-one with Autistic children as a Paraeducator. 

• Mackenzie Gallace is a kindergarten teacher in Pinellas County, Florida.

#phonics #literacy #books  #reading  #readers #teachers #teacher #decoding #decodable #storybooks #school #kindergarten #kindergartenteacher", "reactions_count": 4, "comments_count": null, "reshared_post_author": null, "reshared_post_author_url": null, "reshared_post_author_headline": null, "reshared_post_description": null, "reshared_post_followers": null, "reshared_post_date": null, "last_updated": "2023-02-12 12:02:09", "deleted": 1}, {"id": 40216805, "company_id": 7721630, "urn": "urn:li:activity:6979100873725485057", "followers": 780, "date": "3mo", "description": "The “Science of Reading” (SoR) movement that began in 2018 has gained momentum and has had an outsized influence on state reading policy and classroom practice. However, the SoR movement presents two negative impacts on long-term literacy education—a commitment to the “Simple View” of Reading (SVR) and mandates for phonics-first instruction for all beginning readers. In this webinar, Paul Thomas, Ed.D. (Professor of Education, Furman University, and author of How to End the Reading War and Serve the Literacy Needs of All Students), places the SoR movement within the context of the robust but complex current state of reading science. Come join us on Thursday, October 20, 2022, at 4 p.m. as we explore what’s next in literacy education. Register: https://bit.ly/3qm8aVV

We've recently added three brand-new phonics book sets to our fabulous Digital Reader app—72 decodable readers! 

The Ready, Set, Go books provide the most novice reader with opportunities to develop concepts of print, such as one-to-one matching and return sweep, as well as practice in decoding using consonant sounds and short vowels.

The On Our Way books provide the beginning reader with opportunities to practice decoding CVC words, words with initial and final digraphs, and simple words with initial blends.

The Building Up books provide the early reader with opportunities to practice decoding words with final blends, long vowels, and vowel teams. digitalreader.com

______

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice!

______

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice!

______

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice!

______

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice!

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. ______

September 15th to October 15th is Hispanic or Latinx Heritage Month. This month is dedicated to recognizing and honoring the contributions of Americans with ancestors from a country that speaks Spanish as the primary language: Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, and Spain. While the official designation for the people being celebrated this month is Hispanic, when it comes to describing identity, many different terms are used. For example, Latino/a or Latinx (a gender-neutral alternative) or one’s family’s Country of Origin, such as Mexican or Cuban American, are acceptable, depending on the individual’s preference. I myself am happy to be referred to as Hispanic, Latina, Chicana, or Mexican American. Checking in with others and seeing how they prefer to be identified is always a great practice!

Stepping Together and Phonics Launch students across all grade levels demonstrated significantly higher reading performance as compared to control students. Furthermore, students in kindergarten, grade 1, and grade 2 using Stepping Together and Phonics Launch all demonstrated significantly higher scores in the i-Ready over students that did not use the programs.

Your classroom’s favorite literacy sidekicks are here and ready to save you time, keep student work in one place, and support responsive instruction all year long. ✏️📚

column312: 🎆 Happy 4th of July from Bella, Rosie, Jack, Daisy and all of us at Pioneer Valley Books! As the sky lights up tonight, our favorite pups will be watching the fireworks sparkle (with tails wagging, of course). Wishing you a safe and joyful holiday filled with love, laughter, and a good book or two. 🐾✨
column327:
Teacher Tip! 🌱

Phonics meets knowledge building in this tasty classroom activity inspired by our InfoCodables book on edible plants.

Focus on the digraph ch (as in chop and chomp) and follow these simple steps:

1️⃣ Read together
2️⃣ Have each student complete a “mini fact page”
3️⃣ Combine into a class book or bulletin board!

It’s an engaging, collaborative way to reinforce decoding skills while building content-area vocabulary.

🪴 Tap https://hubs.li/Q03vHd_10 to explore virtual samples of InfoCodables like this one!
column342:
Rusty says “Beep Beep” from #NCSC25! ☀️🚗

We’ve had a blast meeting with you and soaking up some summer fun! 🌼🍧

We’re still here today—last chance to swing by booth #323 and say hi! 💕📚

@therapydogdahlia
column357:
We're all about sparking joyful learning! Come play a round of Fast Four, explore our decodable books, and grab some reading inspiration to take home! 💕📖

Stop by booth #535 at #ASCDAnnual & #ISTELive! 💡📚
column372:
We’re hitting the road this summer! Here’s where you can find us at upcoming education conferences. We’d love to meet you! 🚙👋🏻

The first 150 visitors at each event will receive a FREE decodable book! 🎉

Plus, we’ll have a limited supply of Jasper the Cat shopping totes while they last! 🐾

#NCSC25 (booth is #323) and #ISTELive #ASCDAnnual
column387:
New InfoCodables + Lesson Plans Just Dropped!
Get kids decoding and discovering with three brand-new sets of InfoCodables—18 NEW decodable books. With the purchase of a Digital Reader subscription, you can access a paired digital lesson plan designed to make your planning easier and instruction stronger! 🎉

From Rats in the Wild to Squid-Tastic to Mules Rule, these nonfiction decodables:

✨ Follow the phonics continuum
✨ Build real-world knowledge
✨ Come with ready-to-use digital lesson plans for each title (with a Digital Reader subscription)

📦 Shipping early July

📚 Tap the link in bio to explore the full InfoCodables collection
🔐 Or log in to your Digital Reader to check out the new sets and lesson plans!

🎉 Also, come see us in person! Check out these fantastic books this weekend at #NCSC25 (booth is #323) and #ISTELive #ASCDAnnual
column402:
📚 We’re honored to be included on UFLI’s list of aligned decodable books!

To make it easy for you to access them all, we created four thoughtfully aligned bundles:
✨ Kindergarten
✨ First Grade
✨ Second Grade
✨ Complete K–2

Each set follows the UFLI Foundations scope and sequence and supports strong phonics instruction.

Ready to build confident readers step-by-step?
🔗 https://hubs.li/Q03rV--F0
column417: Join us in Massachusetts and North Carolina this month! If you'll be at NCRA, don't forget to stop by our session to learn all about text sets. 📚
column432: These photos from Jennifer Garris in Risco, MO made us smile today! 🤗 Do your students love Bella & Rosie too? 🐾

column669: President at Center for Teaching/Learning of Mathematics
column753: Your trusted literacy partner for over 25 years, Pioneer Valley Books is dedicated to providing educators with high-quality print and digital resources for comprehensive literacy instruction. We offer engaging books and research-based materials to improve educational outcomes and foster a love of reading. Our robust literacy programs empower educators to create the best possible learning experience for their students.

column14:
Automate your Training & Policy Program:

Password-less access to an OPEN Training Platform

Over 900 "Ready to Go" Security Awareness and Product Training Videos

100+ Phishing Assignments

50+ Phish Email Testing Templates

25 Policy Templates

Full automation on Managing Training, Governance, and Compliance

Automated Dark Web Monitoring and Reporting

Quiz Employees to Test Awareness

Assess and Track your Cyber Program Readiness

Bonus training programs on programs like Teams, HIPAA, QuickBooks, Slack, PayPal, Excel, etc. 

Winner of American Cyber Award's 2020 'Start-Up of the Year'

#CyberSecurity #PasswordSecurity #CyberAwareness #DataBreach", "reactions_count": 4, "comments_count": null, "reshared_post_author": null, "reshared_post_author_url": null, "reshared_post_author_headline": null, "reshared_post_description": null, "reshared_post_followers": null, "reshared_post_date": null, "last_updated": "2025-07-01 16:01:53", "deleted": 0}, {"id": 1103620317, "company_id": 20820752, "urn": "urn:li:activity:7343978920481812480", "followers": 750, "date": "5d", "description": "Catch the final part of Craig Taylor AI + cybersecurity chat with Alexander Carlson. 👇", "reactions_count": 3, "comments_count": 3, "reshared_post_author": "Alexander Carlson", "reshared_post_author_url": "https://www.linkedin.com/in/alex-carlson-digital-pop", "reshared_post_author_headline": "Host of The AI Marketing Navigator - Owner Digital Pop - Performance Digital Marketing", "reshared_post_description": "AI tools are flooding into every workflow—but most companies still have zero written rules for using them.

In Part 3 of my interview with Craig Taylor, CISSP and CEO of CyberHoot, we tackled the missing link: practical AI governance that turns “try this cool bot” chaos into a secure, documented policy.

Why this matters:

- Shadow AI is real. Free meeting bots can record and resell your calls without notice.
- Contract traps lurk in the fine print. Vendors often reserve the right to train their models on your data.
- Regulators and customers now ask for proof that you control data flows—not just promises.

Craig’s playbook for safer AI adoption:

1. Start with six “table-stake” policies
 
WISP, Acceptable Use, Passwords, Data Governance, Patch Management, Incident Response. Use them as scaffolding; trim what doesn’t fit.

2. Bolt on an “Acceptable Use of AI” clause

Require security/managerial sign-off before anyone uploads company data to an AI tool.

3. Vet every AI vendor—fast
 
Drop their TOS into ChatGPT to surface red flags in minutes.

4. Pay (don’t pray) for meeting assistants

Paid tools with clear data-protection terms beat “free” bots monetizing your conversations.

5. Keep training positive

Cyber-literacy programs rooted in practical demos and reinforcement—not fear—drive 90 %+ user satisfaction.

Quick wins you can deploy this week:

- Audit who’s already using AI internally and map the data they share.
- Add a one-page AI usage addendum to your existing Acceptable Use Policy.
- Require password-manager enrollment before granting access to any new AI platform.

Bottom line: Effective AI governance isn’t exotic—it’s disciplined policy hygiene plus smart vendor selection. 

Get your policies in place now, and you’ll harness AI’s upside without opening the door to unnecessary risk.

https://bit.ly/3T14bwv

Don’t miss it! 🎙️", "reactions_count": 1, "comments_count": null, "reshared_post_author": "Alexander Carlson", "reshared_post_author_url": "https://www.linkedin.com/in/alex-carlson-digital-pop", "reshared_post_author_headline": "Host of The AI Marketing Navigator - Owner Digital Pop - Performance Digital Marketing", "reshared_post_description": "AI-powered cybersecurity threats are escalating faster than most organizations realize.

In part 2 of my interview with Craig Taylor, CISSP and CEO of CyberHoot, we dove deeper into the evolving threat landscape. His insights reveal some concerning trends that every business leader should understand.

Current AI-enabled attack vectors:

• Voice cloning scams targeting families and executives - fraudsters can now perfectly replicate voices with minimal audio samples
• Advanced phishing campaigns that analyze social media profiles to create highly personalized attacks
• CEO impersonation attacks using deepfake video calls to authorize fraudulent wire transfers ($50M+ losses reported)
• Malicious unsubscribe links that steal session tokens, bypassing multi-factor authentication
• QR code fraud on parking meters and fake toll violation texts creating artificial urgency

What's keeping cybersecurity experts concerned:

The democratization of sophisticated attack tools. Previously, you needed technical skills to execute complex cyberattacks. Now, AI tools like "Fraud GPT" enable anyone to generate convincing phishing campaigns or write malicious code.

Defensive strategies that actually work:

Craig advocates for positive reinforcement training over traditional fear-based approaches. CyberHoot's gamified platform achieves 90% positive user ratings by focusing on education rather than punishment.

Key elements include establishing family "safe words," implementing passkey authentication where possible, and building genuine cyber literacy skills across organizations.

The bottom line: We're in an arms race between AI-powered attacks and AI-enhanced defenses. Organizations that invest in proper employee education and modern authentication methods will be better positioned to defend against these evolving threats.

https://bit.ly/44d47Pz

Give it a listen! 🎧", "reactions_count": 1, "comments_count": 1, "reshared_post_author": "Alexander Carlson", "reshared_post_author_url": "https://www.linkedin.com/in/alex-carlson-digital-pop", "reshared_post_author_headline": "Host of The AI Marketing Navigator - Owner Digital Pop - Performance Digital Marketing", "reshared_post_description": "Why your cybersecurity training is probably failing (and what actually works instead)

Just had a fascinating conversation with Craig Taylor CISSP and CEO of CyberHoot, who's been in cybersecurity for 25+ years — since before the internet was even a thing.

His biggest revelation? Most companies are doing cybersecurity training completely backwards.

The Problem: 

• Sending phishing tests before proper training (like giving a genetics exam on day one) 
• Fear-based "never click that" messaging without explaining why 
• Boring videos that employees tune out

The Solution: 

Craig advocates for positive reinforcement training that actually changes behavior:

✅ Gamification — employees compete to level up their "cyber owl" avatars 
✅ Education first — explain the WHY behind security practices
✅ Rewards — certificates, continuing education credits, review bonuses 
✅ Engagement — interactive training that translates to real-world email reading 

The AI Factor: 

Plot twist: CyberHoot uses AI to create their training videos (90% positive rating), while simultaneously teaching companies to defend against AI-powered attacks.

As Craig puts it: "When employees understand WHY they shouldn't do something, they're more likely not to do it than if they're just told 'never do that.'"

Bottom line: Stop shocking your employees with surprise phishing tests. Start building their confidence with proper cyber literacy training.

What's your experience with cybersecurity training at your organization?

https://bit.ly/4lxYYIX

Cyber-literacy programs rooted in practical demos and reinforcement—not fear—drive 90 %+ user satisfaction.

Quick wins you can deploy this week:

- Audit who’s already using AI internally and map the data they share.
- Add a one-page AI usage addendum to your existing Acceptable Use Policy.
- Require password-manager enrollment before granting access to any new AI platform.

Bottom line: Effective AI governance isn’t exotic—it’s disciplined policy hygiene plus smart vendor selection. 

Get your policies in place now, and you’ll harness AI’s upside without opening the door to unnecessary risk.

https://bit.ly/3T14bwv

#AI #Cybersecurity #Governance #RiskManagement #Policy
column327: Craig Taylor continues the AI + cybersecurity convo with Alexander Carlson. Don’t miss it! 🎙️
column332: Host of The AI Marketing Navigator - Owner Digital Pop - Performance Digital Marketing
column333:
AI-powered cybersecurity threats are escalating faster than most organizations realize.

In part 2 of my interview with Craig Taylor, CISSP and CEO of CyberHoot, we dove deeper into the evolving threat landscape. His insights reveal some concerning trends that every business leader should understand.

Current AI-enabled attack vectors:

• Voice cloning scams targeting families and executives - fraudsters can now perfectly replicate voices with minimal audio samples
• Advanced phishing campaigns that analyze social media profiles to create highly personalized attacks
• CEO impersonation attacks using deepfake video calls to authorize fraudulent wire transfers ($50M+ losses reported)
• Malicious unsubscribe links that steal session tokens, bypassing multi-factor authentication
• QR code fraud on parking meters and fake toll violation texts creating artificial urgency

What's keeping cybersecurity experts concerned:

The democratization of sophisticated attack tools. Previously, you needed technical skills to execute complex cyberattacks. Now, AI tools like "Fraud GPT" enable anyone to generate convincing phishing campaigns or write malicious code.

Defensive strategies that actually work:

Craig advocates for positive reinforcement training over traditional fear-based approaches. CyberHoot's gamified platform achieves 90% positive user ratings by focusing on education rather than punishment.

Key elements include establishing family "safe words," implementing passkey authentication where possible, and building genuine cyber literacy skills across organizations.

The bottom line: We're in an arms race between AI-powered attacks and AI-enhanced defenses. Organizations that invest in proper employee education and modern authentication methods will be better positioned to defend against these evolving threats.

https://bit.ly/44d47Pz

#Cybersecurity #AI #BusinessSecurity #DigitalTransformation #RiskManagement
column342:
They used to ask if you had antivirus. Now they want MFA, policies, proof of training, and maybe a DNA sample.

In this episode, we expose what carriers really want, the silent deal-breakers hiding in your coverage, and how to protect your business (and your sanity) before the next questionnaire lands in your inbox.

It’s raw. It’s real. And it might just save your next claim.
column357:
AI’s playing for both teams now - defenders and attackers. 🧠⚔️

CyberHoot’s Craig Taylor sat down with Alexander Carlson to unpack what that means for cybersecurity. Give it a listen! 🎧
column362: Host of The AI Marketing Navigator - Owner Digital Pop - Performance Digital Marketing
column363:
Why your cybersecurity training is probably failing (and what actually works instead)

Just had a fascinating conversation with Craig Taylor CISSP and CEO of CyberHoot, who's been in cybersecurity for 25+ years — since before the internet was even a thing.

His biggest revelation? Most companies are doing cybersecurity training completely backwards.

The Problem: 

• Sending phishing tests before proper training (like giving a genetics exam on day one) 
• Fear-based "never click that" messaging without explaining why 
• Boring videos that employees tune out

The Solution: 

Craig advocates for positive reinforcement training that actually changes behavior:

✅ Gamification — employees compete to level up their "cyber owl" avatars 
✅ Education first — explain the WHY behind security practices
✅ Rewards — certificates, continuing education credits, review bonuses 
✅ Engagement — interactive training that translates to real-world email reading 

The AI Factor: 

Plot twist: CyberHoot uses AI to create their training videos (90% positive rating), while simultaneously teaching companies to defend against AI-powered attacks.

As Craig puts it: "When employees understand WHY they shouldn't do something, they're more likely not to do it than if they're just told 'never do that.'"

Bottom line: Stop shocking your employees with surprise phishing tests. Start building their confidence with proper cyber literacy training.

What's your experience with cybersecurity training at your organization?

https://bit.ly/4lxYYIX

#Cybersecurity #EmployeeTraining #AIMarketing #CyberLiteracy #BusinessSecurity
